content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Ryan Morgan: Well, I was born in Boulder, Colorado, and I've spent most of my life here, though I did move around a bit when I was younger. My parents were both pretty educated—my dad has a bachelor's degree, and my mom has a graduate degree. They were both involved in their own careers, though my mom took a break for a while to raise my siblings and me. Growing up, I was always the quiet type, more into books and music than sports or socializing. I was raised Protestant, but I haven't been religious for a while now. I went to a good high school, and while I didn't go to college right away, I've been working on figuring out what I want to do with my life. I'm currently in school, but I'm still trying to decide on a path. I'm not really into politics, but I do care about social issues and want to make sure I'm contributing to the world in a meaningful way.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Ryan Morgan: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was about 18, right after high school, and I had this choice between taking a gap year to travel or starting college right away. I chose the gap year, and it ended up being one of the most pivotal decisions I've made. I spent six months traveling through Europe and South America, mostly on a budget, staying with host families, working odd jobs, and just immersing myself in different cultures. It opened my eyes to so much—how different people live, the struggles they face, and how interconnected we all are. When I came back, I felt like I had a clearer sense of who I was and what I wanted. I started college with a more focused mindset, even though I'm still figuring things out. That experience really shaped my worldview and my desire to make a difference, even if I'm not sure exactly how yet.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Ryan Morgan: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way most people might expect. I wasn't just deciding between two clear options—I was trying to figure out what I even wanted. I remember sitting on a train in Spain, watching the landscape roll by, and realizing that I didn't want to just follow the path everyone else expected of me. I wanted to understand the world beyond what I'd been taught, beyond what my parents had built for me. So I made the decision to step out of that comfort zone, even though it scared me. I didn't have a plan, but I knew I needed to experience life before I could commit to a future. In that way, it was a choice, but it also felt like something I needed to do, almost like a part of me had been waiting for that moment to act.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Ryan Morgan: Looking back, I think my parents were definitely there for me, even if they didn't push me to take the gap year. They supported my decision once I made it, which meant a lot. But I also think traveling alone, without a structured plan, forced me to rely on myself in ways I hadn't before. I met people along the way who helped me see things differently—like a teacher in Peru who encouraged me to think about education as a tool for change, or a friend in Barcelona who showed me how to be more open and adaptable. I don't know if I would have had the same experience without those people, but I also think I needed to be in that situation to find them. It was a mix of support from others and my own need to grow that got me through that time.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Ryan Morgan: Right now, I don't have a partner or any children. I've been focused on my education and figuring out my path, so relationships haven't really been a big part of my life yet. My family is still pretty important to me, though. My parents are both still in Boulder, and we talk often. My mom recently went back to work part-time, which has been a big shift for her, and my dad is still in his field, though he's thinking about retiring soon. I have a younger sister who's in college, and we're pretty close. She's the more outgoing one, so I think I got the quiet genes. I admire her for taking charge of her life, and I hope to be as sure of myself as she is one day. Family has always been a big part of my life, even if I haven't always been the most connected with them. I think I'm learning to balance my independence with staying close to them.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by choices, both big and small. Starting with the story of my life, I realized how much my upbringing in Boulder, my quiet nature, and my education have influenced who I am today. The crossroads I mentioned—choosing a gap year over college—was a turning point that opened my eyes to the world and my place in it. It wasn't just a decision; it was a moment of self-discovery that I needed to make on my own, even if others supported me along the way. Thinking about my family now, I see how much they've been a constant in my life, even as I've been figuring out my own path. It's interesting how these questions brought everything together, showing me how my past has led me to where I am today, and how I still have so much to learn and grow from.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Ryan Morgan: My grandparents are still around, though they live in a smaller town a few hours away from Boulder. My grandfather on my dad's side is a retired teacher, and he's always been a big influence on me. He used to tell me stories about his students and how education could change lives, which I think is what sparked my interest in wanting to make a difference somehow. My grandmother on my mom's side is more reserved, but she's always been there for me with quiet support. I don't see them as often as I'd like, but whenever I do, it feels like a homecoming. They've both been through a lot, and I respect them for that. I think they've shaped me in ways I'm only starting to understand, especially in how they've handled life's challenges with grace and resilience.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Ryan Morgan: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me, especially during the time I was traveling. One of them, Alex, I met in Barcelona while I was volunteering at a community center there. He was a local artist, and we bonded over music and our shared interest in social issues. He taught me how to see the world through a more creative lens and encouraged me to think about how art can be a form of activism. Even though we haven't stayed in touch as much since I came back, I still think about him and the impact he had on me. There's also Sam, who I met in Peru—she was a fellow traveler, but she ended up staying in South America for a few years to work with indigenous communities. She's the one who really opened my eyes to the importance of cultural preservation and sustainability. I don't see her often, but I admire her dedication and the way she's built a life around her values. These people, even though they're not family, have shaped my perspective in ways that I'm still trying to understand. They've shown me that life isn't just about following a path—it's about being open to the people and experiences that challenge you along the way.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Ryan Morgan: I live in a small apartment in downtown Boulder, just a few blocks from the university. It's a pretty laid-back neighborhood, with a lot of students, artists, and people who care about sustainability. There are a lot of coffee shops, bookstores, and little indie theaters, which fits with my personality—I like the quiet energy of a place that's always buzzing with creativity but never too loud. The apartment itself is cozy, with a lot of natural light and plants, which I try to keep alive. I rent it from an older couple who run a small organic grocery store nearby. They're both retired teachers, and they've been really supportive of me, even though I'm still figuring things out. Living here feels like a good balance between being close to the resources I need for school and having a space that feels like my own. I also like that Boulder is pretty walkable, so I can get to campus, the library, or even the mountains without needing a car. It's not perfect—rent is expensive, and sometimes it's hard to find quiet time with all the activity around—but overall, it's a place that feels like it's in line with who I am and what I'm trying to become.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Ryan Morgan: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. Boulder is a pretty tight-knit community, and even though there are students and artists around, there's a general sense of respect and care for one another. I've never felt threatened or unsafe in my neighborhood, which is something I appreciate. The people here are usually friendly, and even if I don't know someone, they tend to be welcoming. I think it also helps that the area is well-lit and there's always some kind of activity going on, whether it's a street fair, a protest, or just people hanging out in the parks. It's not the kind of place where you'd feel alone or vulnerable, which is nice, especially for someone like me who's still figuring out their place in the world.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Ryan Morgan: Living here has had its ups and downs, for sure. On the positive side, being close to campus and all the cultural spots makes it easy to stay engaged with what's going on—whether it's a lecture I'm interested in, a new art exhibit, or a protest about something I care about. I love that there's always something happening, and it keeps me from getting too stuck in my own head. But the downs? Well, rent is definitely a struggle. I work part-time at a bookstore to help cover some of the costs, but it's not enough to live comfortably. I also find that with so many people around, it can be hard to find real quiet time—something I really need to focus and reflect. I've had to get creative, like setting up a small meditation corner in my apartment or going up to the mountains on the weekends to clear my mind. It's not perfect, but I think it's working. This place has challenged me, but it's also given me a lot—community, opportunity, and a sense of belonging that I didn't expect.

Going through the questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety made me realize how much my environment shapes who I am and how I see the world. Talking about my family reminded me of how important they've been in my life, even as I've been trying to find my own path. My parents, my sister, and even my grandparents have all played a role in who I am today, whether through their support, their stories, or their example. Then, when I talked about my neighborhood, it felt like I was describing a part of myself—this small, creative, and welcoming place in Boulder that mirrors the kind of person I'm trying to become. I never really thought about how much my sense of safety and comfort in this place affects my ability to grow and explore. It's not just where I live; it's a foundation that lets me take risks, like going back to school or thinking about how I want to contribute to the world. And even though there are challenges, like the cost of living or finding quiet time, I feel like I'm in a place that's helping me learn and evolve. It's interesting how these questions brought it all together, showing me how my past, my family, and my present environment are all connected in shaping the person I am now.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Ryan Morgan: A typical week for me is pretty varied, but there's a rhythm to it. I usually start my week with classes—most of my courses are in the mornings, which I find helps me stay focused. After class, I work part-time at the bookstore, which is a good way to meet people and keep my mind active. Midweek, I try to make time for some kind of creative outlet—whether it's writing, reading, or even just sketching in my notebook. I also have a few study groups that meet on Tuesdays and Thursdays, which are both productive and social. Fridays are usually my busiest day because I have more classes and then I often go to a local event or performance downtown. Saturdays are more relaxed—I might go hiking in the nearby mountains or just spend the day at a café, reading or catching up with friends. Sundays are my day to recharge. I try to keep it quiet, maybe do some light reading or write in my journal. It's not always perfect, but I like that my week has a mix of structure and flexibility. It keeps me grounded but also gives me space to explore and grow.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Ryan Morgan: I work part-time at a small independent bookstore called 'Page Turner's,' which is just a few blocks from my apartment. I usually work weekends, though I sometimes swap shifts with the manager to have a few weekday evenings free for studying or meeting up with friends. The job is pretty flexible, which is good because I'm still figuring out my schedule with school. I enjoy working there because the owner, a retired literature professor, has a great sense of humor and always shares interesting stories about the books we sell. It's a calm place compared to the rest of the city, and it gives me a chance to slow down and think. I also help out with organizing events like poetry nights and author readings, which I find really rewarding. It's not a high-paying job, but it's meaningful to me, and I feel like I'm contributing to something I care about—literacy, community, and the power of stories.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Ryan Morgan: Outside of work and school, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to meditate for at least 10 minutes each morning, even if it's just sitting in silence with my coffee. It's something I started during my travels, and it's become a small but meaningful way to center myself. I also make it a point to read every night, usually fiction or poetry—something that takes me out of my head and into another world. I've been trying to get back into journaling again, too, just to track my thoughts and feelings, especially as I navigate this phase of my life. It's not always easy to be introspective, but I think these little habits help me stay connected to who I am, even when everything else feels uncertain.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Ryan Morgan: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more physical activity into my week. I used to be pretty sedentary, especially during the school year when I was spending most of my time in the library or at the bookstore. But after a few months of feeling sluggish and mentally drained, I decided to start going for morning runs along the Boulder Creek Path. It's a beautiful route, with the mountains in the background and the sound of the water, and it helps me wake up and feel more present. I also started attending a weekly yoga class at a local studio, which has been a nice balance to the running. It's funny how something as simple as moving your body can make such a difference in how you feel overall. I think it's part of my ongoing effort to take better care of myself, both physically and mentally, as I continue to explore what I want my life to look like.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Ryan Morgan: I don't have children yet, so I can't really speak to what a typical weekday would look like for them. But I can imagine that if I did, I'd want to make sure they had a balance of structure and freedom—like the kind of environment I grew up in. I think it's important for kids to have time to explore their interests, whether that's through sports, music, or just playing outside. I'd also want them to feel supported in their education, maybe even encourage them to take a gap year or travel if they felt called to it, just like I did. It's funny how something that wasn't part of my life until recently is now something I'm thinking about in a different way. I guess it's part of growing up and realizing that the choices I make now might shape the lives of others in the future.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my environment and daily routines shape who I am and how I navigate the world. Talking about my family reminded me of the roots I come from—the support, the stories, and the quiet strength that have been passed down through generations. It made me realize how much I carry with me, even as I try to carve out my own path. Then, when I described my neighborhood and the sense of safety and community it offers, it felt like I was describing a part of myself that I didn't fully recognize until now. It's not just where I live; it's how I feel when I'm there, how I grow, and how I'm able to take risks. And when I talked about my daily routines—work, study, meditation, reading, and even running—it made me see how small, consistent habits can have a big impact on my mental and physical well-being. I've always thought of these things as separate parts of my life, but now I see how they're all connected, shaping the person I am and the person I'm trying to become.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Ryan Morgan: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in pretty good shape, though I've had my share of ups and downs. I've always been more of a low-energy person, not someone who's naturally athletic, but I've been making an effort to take better care of myself lately. I used to struggle with anxiety, especially during my gap year when I was constantly moving and trying to figure things out. It wasn't anything too severe, but it did affect how I felt about myself and my ability to focus. I started seeing a therapist a few years back, and that helped a lot. I learned some coping strategies, like journaling and mindfulness, which I still use today. I also used to have trouble sleeping—sometimes I'd lie awake for hours thinking about everything I needed to do or all the things I wasn't sure about. But since I started meditating and running in the mornings, my sleep has improved a lot. I still have days where I feel overwhelmed, but I'm more aware of how to manage it now. Overall, I think I'm in a better place than I was a few years ago, and I'm trying to keep that momentum going.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Ryan Morgan: For me, staying healthy is a mix of what makes it easy and what makes it hard. On the easy side, I think the community here in Boulder plays a big role. There's always something going on—whether it's a yoga class, a run along the creek, or just a friendly chat at the bookstore—that keeps me motivated to take care of myself. I also find that having small, consistent routines—like my morning meditation or evening reading—helps me feel more grounded and in control. But on the harder side, it's the constant pressure of figuring things out. I'm still in school, I'm still trying to decide what I want to do with my life, and that uncertainty can be really draining. Sometimes, I feel like I'm stretching myself too thin, trying to balance work, school, and personal growth all at once. That can lead to burnout, especially when I'm not sleeping well or when I'm not taking enough time to just be still. I think the biggest challenge is learning how to say no to things that don't serve me, and how to prioritize my well-being without feeling guilty about it. It's a work in progress, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself in the process.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Ryan Morgan: In the past two years, I haven't had any major medical diagnoses or serious injuries, which I'm grateful for. The biggest thing related to my health was actually a period of increased anxiety and burnout that I mentioned earlier, which I've been working through with therapy and self-care. I also had a minor flare-up of some old back pain I used to get when I was younger, probably from sitting too long in classes or at the bookstore. It wasn't anything too bad, but it reminded me how important it is to take breaks and move my body regularly. I started seeing a physical therapist for a few sessions, and that helped me understand how to sit and stand in ways that don't strain my back. It was a small but important reminder that my health isn't just about mental well-being—it's also about how I take care of my body day to day. I think that's something I need to keep in mind as I continue to grow and explore what I want my life to look like.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Ryan Morgan: Honestly, I don't think my health has ever really gotten in the way of what I need to do, but I can see how it could. The anxiety I've dealt with, especially during my gap year and in the early days of college, did make it harder to focus sometimes. I remember there were days when I'd feel so overwhelmed by everything—school, work, trying to figure out my future—that I'd just shut down. It wasn't that I couldn't work or take care of myself, but I had to be really intentional about it. I think the biggest thing is that I've learned to listen to my body and mind more now. If I feel like I'm burning out, I take a step back, even if it's just for a day. I've also started setting boundaries more clearly, which helps me avoid the kind of stress that leads to burnout. I don't know if I'd be able to handle everything as well as I do now if I hadn't made those changes. It's not perfect, but it's a start.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Ryan Morgan: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—growth, uncertainty, and a quiet sense of purpose. There's been a lot of change, both in my personal life and in the world around me. I've been trying to stay grounded through my routines, like my morning runs and meditation, but there have been moments when the weight of everything feels heavy. I think a lot of it has to do with the uncertainty of my future. I'm in school, I'm working, I'm trying to figure out what I want to do with my life, and sometimes it all feels like too much. But at the same time, I feel like I'm moving forward, even if it's not in a straight line. I've been more aware of my mental health lately, and I've been trying to be kinder to myself when things don't go as planned. I also feel more connected to my community here in Boulder, which has been a source of comfort and inspiration. There have been days when I feel like I'm exactly where I need to be, and other days when I wonder if I'm just drifting. But overall, I think I'm learning to embrace the process, even when it's messy.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily habits influence my overall well-being and sense of self. Talking about my recent changes, like incorporating morning runs and yoga into my routine, reminded me how small, consistent actions can have a big impact on how I feel physically and mentally. It also made me think about the balance between taking care of myself and the pressures of figuring out my future. I used to see my health as something separate from my goals and identity, but now I realize it's deeply connected to everything else. The challenges I've faced with anxiety and burnout have taught me the importance of listening to my body and mind, and I'm trying to be more intentional about my self-care. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of myself isn't a luxury—it's a necessity, especially when I'm navigating the uncertainties of life.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Ryan Morgan: I think I've struggled with anxiety at times, especially during periods of transition or uncertainty. It's not something I've always been open about, but looking back, I can see how it's shaped a lot of my decisions and how I've approached life. There were definitely moments during my gap year when I felt overwhelmed by the sheer amount of change and the pressure to figure things out on my own. I remember lying awake at night, worrying about whether I was making the right choices or if I was just wasting time. It wasn't clinical depression, but it was a form of emotional exhaustion that made it hard to stay motivated or feel connected to the world around me. Over time, I've learned to recognize the signs and take steps to manage it—whether that's through talking to someone, meditating, or just giving myself permission to rest. I think the biggest thing is that I've come to see anxiety not as something to be ashamed of, but as a part of being human. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to navigate it in ways that help me stay grounded and keep moving forward.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Ryan Morgan: For my family, it's been a year of adjustments and quiet resilience. My mom, after taking a break from work for so long, has been navigating the transition back into the workforce, which has been both exciting and challenging for her. She's been working part-time now, and while she's happy to be contributing again, she's also had to learn how to balance that with being a mom and a grandmother. My dad, on the other hand, has been thinking more about retirement, which has brought up a lot of conversations about what comes next for him. He's always been the steady one, the one who provided the foundation, and now he's starting to look at life beyond that role. My sister, she's been going through her own journey in college, figuring out her major and her future. She's always been the more confident one, the one who knows what she wants, but even she has her doubts sometimes. It's been interesting to see how each of us is dealing with change in our own way, even if we're all part of the same family. I think it's made us closer in some ways, even if we're not always in the same place or going through the same things. There's a kind of unspoken understanding that we're all growing, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Ryan Morgan: I think I've always been more of a spiritual person than a religious one, even though I was raised Protestant. As I got older, I found that the strict structure of organized religion didn't quite fit with how I saw the world. I still respect the values and traditions that come with it, but I've come to see spirituality more as a personal journey—one that's about connection, reflection, and finding meaning in the small things. I don't go to church or follow any specific doctrine, but I do find peace in nature, in quiet moments, and in the idea that there's something bigger than myself. I think that's why I've always been drawn to places like Boulder, where the mountains feel like they're part of something ancient and eternal. It's not about belief in a higher power in the traditional sense, but more about being present, being grateful, and understanding that life is full of mysteries we may never fully grasp. I think that's enough for me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Ryan Morgan: I don't use social media all that much, honestly. I've always been more of a private person, and I find that platforms like Facebook or Instagram can be overwhelming with all the noise and comparison. I do follow a few accounts that inspire me—like environmental activists, writers, or people who share thoughtful reflections on life—but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or engaging with posts. I think it's more about what I consume offline, like books, conversations with friends, or just being in nature. I do use my phone to stay in touch with family, especially my sister and parents, and I'll sometimes post a photo of a sunset or a book I'm reading if I feel like sharing it, but it's not a big part of my life. I guess I've always preferred real connections over digital ones, even if that makes me a bit of an old soul in this age of constant connectivity.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Ryan Morgan: Honestly, I don't think I've relied on social media for support in the way some people do. I've always found that my emotional support comes from real, face-to-face connections—whether it's my family, my friends, or even the people I meet at the bookstore. That said, I do think there's value in having a space to share thoughts or feel seen, even if it's online. I've followed a few mental health advocates on Twitter who post about self-care and mindfulness, and sometimes their words resonate with me in a way that feels comforting. But I don't really see myself as someone who needs to broadcast my struggles or seek validation through likes or comments. I think I've always preferred to process things privately, even if that means I don't always reach out for help when I need it. I'm learning, though—that sometimes asking for support, even in small ways, can make a big difference.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how deeply my health and mental well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about my past struggles with anxiety and burnout reminded me of how much I've grown in learning to listen to my body and mind. I used to see my mental health as something separate from my goals and identity, but now I realize it's deeply connected to everything else. The challenges I've faced with uncertainty and pressure have taught me the importance of self-compassion and setting boundaries. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of myself isn't a luxury—it's a necessity, especially when I'm navigating the uncertainties of life. I also felt a sense of gratitude for the support I've received from my family and the small but meaningful changes I've made in my daily habits, like morning runs and meditation. These things have helped me stay grounded and reminded me that even in the messiest of times, there's still a path forward.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Ryan Morgan: In the past few months, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted a bit—less intense, but more persistent. It's not the all-consuming anxiety I used to feel, but there's this constant undercurrent of worry about the future, about whether I'm making the right choices, or if I'm just wasting time. I think part of it is the pressure of being in school while still trying to figure out what I want to do with my life. I've been using a few new coping strategies to manage it. One of them is journaling more regularly, not just for reflection but also as a way to offload my thoughts onto paper instead of keeping them inside. I've also been trying to be more intentional about my time—scheduling breaks, setting clear boundaries between work and rest, and even saying no to things that don't align with my goals. I've found that when I'm able to structure my days with purpose, it helps quiet the noise in my head. I'm still learning, though. Some days I feel like I'm making progress, and others I feel like I'm just going through the motions. But I think that's part of the process—accepting that growth isn't linear, and that it's okay to stumble along the way.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Ryan Morgan: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. Rent is the largest chunk—my apartment is cozy but not cheap, especially in Boulder. I work part-time at the bookstore, which helps, but it's not enough to cover everything, so I have to be careful with how I spend. Groceries are another big one, especially since I try to eat healthily with a lot of fresh produce and whole foods. I also spend a bit on public transportation, though I walk a lot and only use the bus occasionally. I've been trying to cut back on non-essentials like eating out or buying new clothes, but it's tough when you're still figuring things out. I also set aside a small amount each month for books and supplies, since I'm in school and always need new materials. It's a tight budget, but I've learned to prioritize what's important and find ways to stretch my money without sacrificing my well-being.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Ryan Morgan: To be honest, my monthly spending has been pretty consistent lately, though there are always fluctuations depending on what's going on. Last month, I spent around $1,800, which is about what I usually do. Rent takes up the biggest chunk—around $1,000—then groceries, which are about $400, and transportation, maybe $100. I also set aside $150 for books and school supplies, and another $150 for miscellaneous things like utilities, internet, and the occasional meal out. It's not a lot, but I've gotten pretty good at managing it. I track my expenses in a simple spreadsheet, and I try to stick to a budget that prioritizes what's essential. Sometimes I feel like I'm always one step away from needing to cut something else, but I've learned to be resourceful—like buying secondhand books or using coupons for groceries. It's not always easy, but I think it's part of growing up and learning how to take care of myself without relying on others too much.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Ryan Morgan: We rent our home, actually. I live in a small apartment downtown, which I mentioned earlier. It's a one-bedroom place, and I've been there for about a year now. Renting makes the most sense for me right now because I'm still in school and figuring out my long-term plans. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon, especially with the cost of living here. I like the flexibility of renting—it allows me to be close to campus and the community without the long-term commitment of homeownership. Plus, it's easier to move if I decide to take a gap year or travel again in the future. I've been lucky to find a place that's both affordable and comfortable, even if it's not extravagant. It's just enough to give me a sense of stability while I continue to explore what I want my life to look like.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Ryan Morgan: Over the past year, my bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the different things that come up. In the winter, for example, my heating bill went up a bit, which I hadn't really anticipated. I thought I was used to the cold, but living in a small apartment with just one heater made a difference. I also noticed that my electricity bill tends to be higher in the summer when I'm using more lights and fans, especially since I've been staying up later to read or work on assignments. Holidays were another thing—around Christmas, I had to spend a little more on groceries and a small gift for my parents, which I hadn't budgeted for. Then there were the months when I had to pay for a few unexpected things, like a new pair of running shoes or a book I needed for a class. It's funny how these small expenses can add up, but I've learned to be more mindful of them. I've started setting aside a little extra each month for these kinds of things, just in case. It's not perfect, but it helps me feel more in control of my finances, even if I'm still figuring out how to balance everything.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and my approach to social media have shaped my emotional well-being and sense of connection. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they've been a source of strength and support, even as we all navigate our own paths of growth and change. It's interesting how, even when we're not all in the same place or going through the same things, there's still a quiet understanding that we're all learning and growing together. Then, when I talked about my use of social media, it made me think about how I've always preferred real, face-to-face connections over digital ones. I've always found that the noise and comparison on platforms like Facebook or Instagram can be overwhelming, and I've chosen to focus more on what matters—like conversations with friends, time in nature, or just being present in the moment. I think that's why I've found peace in my current life, even with all the uncertainty. It's not about avoiding the world or the challenges it brings, but about choosing what nourishes me and letting go of what doesn't. I'm learning that connection doesn't always have to be loud or visible—it can be quiet, meaningful, and deeply personal.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Ryan Morgan: I've always tried to save, even if it's not a lot. Right now, I have a small savings account that I contribute to every month, even if it's just $50 or so. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of security, especially when I'm trying to navigate all the uncertainties of school and life. I also save in a more informal way—like setting aside extra money from tips at the bookstore or from selling books I no longer need. I think it's important to have some kind of financial cushion, even if it's not a huge amount. It's not about being rich or having everything figured out; it's more about being prepared for the unexpected. I've learned that saving, even in small ways, helps me feel more in control and less anxious about the future.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Ryan Morgan: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for any specific big purchase. I know I'm not in a position to buy a house or even a car anytime soon, so I've focused on building a small emergency fund. It's not a lot—maybe around $500 or so—but it gives me peace of mind knowing that if something unexpected comes up, like a medical bill or a sudden need for repairs, I won't be completely caught off guard. I also try to save a little extra when I have the chance, like when I get a bonus from the bookstore or when I sell books I no longer need. It's not about having a lot; it's about being prepared, even in small ways. I think that's something I've learned from watching my parents—my mom, in particular, always emphasized the importance of being responsible with money, even when times were tight. I want to carry that lesson with me as I continue to grow and figure out what the future holds.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Ryan Morgan: My current occupation is a part-time student and part-time bookseller, but if I had to define it more broadly, I'd say I'm in the process of becoming something—still figuring out what that is. Right now, my most important activities revolve around my studies, which are in the field of environmental studies, and my work at the bookstore, where I help curate collections, assist customers, and organize events like poetry nights and author readings. I also spend a lot of time reflecting, journaling, and engaging with the community through small acts of service, like volunteering at a local literacy program or helping out at a community garden. The most important duties, I think, are the ones that help me stay connected to my values—whether that's through learning about sustainability, supporting local artists and writers, or simply being present for the people around me. It's not a traditional job, but I think it's the kind of work that aligns with who I am and what I hope to contribute to the world.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Ryan Morgan: I usually work around 15 to 20 hours a week, depending on the semester and how busy the bookstore gets. During exam weeks or when there are a lot of events, like poetry nights or author readings, I might pick up a few extra shifts. But on average, it's about 15 hours—mostly on weekends, with some weekday evenings if I need the extra income. It's not a lot, but it helps cover my expenses and gives me a sense of purpose. I like the flexibility, and I find that working at the bookstore allows me to be part of something bigger than just earning a paycheck. It's a way to connect with people, support local writers, and stay engaged with the community. I think that's why I've stayed with it even when the hours aren't ideal—it feels meaningful in a way that just making money wouldn't.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Ryan Morgan: I didn't have more than one job at the same time, but I did take on a few different roles in the past, especially during my gap year. For example, I worked as a volunteer at a community center in Barcelona, helping with language classes for immigrants, and I also did some odd jobs like teaching English to locals or helping out at a small café. It wasn't always the most stable work, but it gave me a sense of purpose and kept me financially afloat while I was traveling. I think those experiences helped me understand the value of different kinds of work—not just in terms of money, but in how they connect you to people and places. Now, with my part-time job at the bookstore and my studies, I feel like I'm in a more stable place, but I still appreciate the diversity of experiences that came from having multiple roles in the past.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my emotional well-being, financial stability, and connections with others are all intertwined in shaping my daily life. Talking about my stress and coping strategies reminded me of how much I've grown in learning to manage uncertainty and anxiety, even if it's still a work in progress. It also made me think about how my financial situation—rent, groceries, and budgeting—has a real impact on my mental health and sense of security. I used to see these things as separate parts of my life, but now I see how they all affect one another. My family has always been a source of support, and even though we're all navigating our own paths, I feel grateful for their presence in my life. I'm also learning that connection doesn't always have to be loud or visible—it can be quiet, meaningful, and deeply personal. It's not about having everything figured out, but about being present, being kind to myself, and finding small ways to take care of both my mind and my wallet.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Ryan Morgan: In terms of income, my household—just me—made around $1,200 last month from my part-time job at the bookstore. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover my basic needs, especially since I'm still in school and not paying for a lot of other expenses. I also get a small stipend from a scholarship program I was accepted into, which helps with books and supplies. It's not a huge amount, but it gives me a little more breathing room. I've learned to be really careful with my money, and I try to live within my means as much as possible. I know it's not the same as having a full-time job or a steady income, but I'm trying to make the most of what I have and use it in ways that align with my values—like supporting local businesses, buying secondhand when I can, and investing in things that help me grow, like courses or books. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that financial stability doesn't have to mean wealth—it can just mean being able to meet your needs and have a little something left over for the things that matter.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Ryan Morgan: I've been working at Page Turner's for about a year now, and it's been a really rewarding experience. The benefits aren't the traditional ones you get with a full-time job—there's no health insurance or paid vacation, but what I do get is something just as valuable: a sense of community and purpose. The owner, Mr. Halstead, is more than just a boss; he's like a mentor. He's always encouraging me to think critically about the books we sell and the stories they tell. He also gives me the freedom to take time off when I need it, whether it's for a morning run, a meditation session, or just to recharge. I don't think I'd be as grounded or as connected to my values if I didn't have this job. It's not about the money—it's about the people, the conversations, and the little moments that remind me why I care about what I do.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Ryan Morgan: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a good rapport with my manager, Mr. Halstead—he's been a big influence on me, not just as a boss but as someone who genuinely cares about the people who work there. He's always been supportive of my interests, whether it's recommending a book I might like or encouraging me to take time for myself when I need it. As for my coworkers, we get along well. Most of them are students or local artists, so there's a shared understanding of the pace of life here. We have these little conversations about books, music, or even just the weather, and it makes the work feel less like a job and more like being part of a community. I think that's one of the reasons I've stayed at the bookstore—it's not just about selling books; it's about connecting with people and being part of something that matters to me.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Ryan Morgan: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which is one of the things I appreciate most about the job. I usually work weekends, but I can swap shifts with the manager or other coworkers if I need more free time during the week. It's not the kind of schedule that's set in stone, which is both a blessing and a challenge. On one hand, it gives me the freedom to adjust my hours based on my classes or personal needs, like needing an early morning to run or a quiet evening to read. On the other hand, it means I have to be proactive about planning my week and making sure I don't overcommit. I've learned to communicate openly with Mr. Halstead and my coworkers about my availability, and they're always understanding. It's not perfect, but I think the flexibility is worth it—it allows me to balance work, school, and the little things that keep me grounded, like time in nature or just being present in the moment.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Ryan Morgan: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but it's definitely a balancing act. I'm not struggling in the way that would make me worry about basic needs, but I'm also not in a position where I can afford luxuries or take big risks. It's a tightrope walk between being responsible with what I have and still allowing myself the space to grow and explore. I know I'm not alone in this—so many people my age are in the same boat, trying to figure out how to make ends meet while also building a future. What keeps me going is the fact that I'm not just surviving; I'm learning, I'm connected to a community that supports me, and I'm slowly building something that feels meaningful. I don't know what the future holds financially, but I'm trying to stay grounded in the present, knowing that every small step I take is part of a bigger journey.

Going through the questions about my bills, savings, and work has made me reflect on how much my financial situation shapes my daily life and sense of security. Talking about how my bills fluctuate with the seasons and unexpected expenses reminded me of how much I've had to adapt and be mindful of my spending. It's not just about numbers on a spreadsheet—it's about making choices that allow me to live with purpose while still being responsible. Then, when I discussed my savings and the small amounts I set aside, it made me realize how important it is to have even a little financial cushion, no matter how modest. It's not about being rich, but about feeling prepared for the unexpected. And when I talked about my job at the bookstore and the flexibility it offers, it made me appreciate how much that role contributes to my sense of stability and connection. I used to see these things as separate parts of my life—money, work, and personal growth—but now I see how they all tie together in shaping who I am and how I navigate the world.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Ryan Morgan: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their situations were a bit different. My dad was pretty consistent in his job—he worked in education administration for most of my childhood, and he was always the steady presence in our household. He never had to worry about job security, which gave my mom the flexibility to take a break for a while when we were younger. She worked part-time for a few years after I was born, but then she took a step back to focus on raising my sister and me. It wasn't easy, but she always said she wanted to be there for us, even if it meant sacrificing some of her own ambitions. Looking back, I think that choice shaped a lot of how I see family and responsibility. It also made me more aware of the value of education and stability, which is why I've always been drawn to learning and trying to build a future that feels secure, even if it's not perfect.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Ryan Morgan: My dad worked in education administration, which meant he was involved in things like curriculum development, school policy, and supporting teachers and staff. He was the kind of person who believed that education was the foundation of everything, and he always encouraged us to ask questions and think critically. His most important duties revolved around making sure that schools had the resources they needed and that teachers felt supported. He was never one to chase promotions or big titles—he just wanted to make sure that the system worked for the people in it. My mom, on the other hand, worked part-time as a counselor in a community center for a while. She helped people with everything from housing assistance to mental health support. It was a tough job, but she was really passionate about it. She always said that the most important part of her work was listening—really listening to people and helping them find their way. I think both of their jobs taught me something about responsibility, empathy, and the value of helping others, even in small ways. It's something I carry with me every day, whether I'm working at the bookstore or just trying to figure out my own path.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Ryan Morgan: My dad worked for a public school district in Boulder, and his role was more administrative than hands-on in the classroom. He was part of a team that oversaw curriculum development, teacher training, and school policies. He spent a lot of time meeting with educators, reviewing materials, and making sure that the district had the resources it needed to support students and staff. He always said his job was about creating a system that allowed teachers to do what they did best—teach. As for my mom, she worked for a nonprofit community center that provided support services for people in need. She was a counselor, but not in the traditional sense—she helped people with housing, food assistance, and mental health resources. She didn't make a lot of money, but she always said that the work she did mattered more than the paycheck. I think that's why I've always felt a bit of a responsibility to use what I have in a way that helps others, even if I'm still figuring out exactly how to do that.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Ryan Morgan: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in Boulder, but maybe with a little more clarity about what I want to do with my life. I don't know if I'll be in school full-time or if I'll have taken a different path altogether, but I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still connected to the people and ideas that matter to me. I'd like to think I've found a way to balance my need for independence with the support of family and friends. I also hope I'm doing something that feels meaningful—whether it's working in education, environmental advocacy, or something else that aligns with my values. I don't want to be stuck in a job just for the sake of making money; I want to be doing something that makes a difference, even in small ways. And I hope I'm still running in the mornings, still reading, and still finding peace in the quiet moments. I think that's the kind of life I want—not one that's perfect, but one that feels authentic and full of purpose.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Ryan Morgan: What I value the most in my life is connection—both to people and to the world around me. I think it's what keeps me grounded, especially when everything else feels uncertain. I value the quiet conversations with my parents, the way my grandparents have always had a kind of wisdom that comes from living through so much, and the friendships I've built, even if they're not always easy to maintain. I also value the small, meaningful things—the sound of rain on the windows, the smell of a well-worn book, the way the mountains feel like they've always been there, watching over me. I think I value growth, too—not the kind of growth that's about achieving something specific, but the kind that happens when you're open to change, when you're willing to sit with uncertainty and still find a way forward. It's not always easy, but I think it's what makes life worth living.

It's not about having a lot of money, but about making choices that allow me to live with intention and contribute to the world in small, meaningful ways. Then, when I described my job at the bookstore and the relationships I've built there, it made me realize how much that role has become a part of who I am. It's not just about the work itself, but the people, the conversations, and the sense of community that come with it. I used to see these things as separate parts of my life—money, work, and personal growth—but now I see how they all influence one another. It's a reminder that even in the midst of uncertainty, there are things that ground me and give me a sense of direction.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of self-discovery, reflection, and connection. It's amazing how much of who I am has been shaped by the people, places, and experiences I've had—my family's influence, the quiet nature I've always carried, the pivotal decision to take a gap year, and the ongoing exploration of what I want my life to look like. It's also been a reminder of how deeply my environment, from my neighborhood in Boulder to my job at the bookstore, has played a role in shaping my values, my sense of purpose, and my daily routines. I've come to see that my life isn't just a series of isolated moments, but a tapestry of interconnected choices, relationships, and growth. This process has helped me understand that I don't need to have everything figured out to be moving forward—I just need to stay open, stay connected, and keep learning. I'm grateful for the journey so far, and I'm excited to see where it leads me next.
